title: 5 Ways to Stir Up Your Irish-Self

seo_title: 5 Ways to Stir Up Your Irish-Self
long_description:
When St. Patrick’s Day arrives, Irish pubs around the world become inundated with green beer and shamrocks. But this holiday has the potential to be enlightening to anyone interested in dipping their toes into Irish heritage in New York City.  

 

McSorley’s Old Ale House

Proudly open since before any of us was born, McSorley’s Old Ale House is where you’ll get good pint of ale and your history fix. Abraham Lincoln was here, the Prohibition era moved the saloon to a dingy basement and women were first admitted in 1970. A lot has happened in this joint and coming here means you’ll be part if its history as well.  

 

Tenement Museum

During the tragic Irish famine in the 19th century, countless Irish immigrants journeyed to New York in search of a better life. Except that they didn’t quite find it. The Lower East Side became a hub for poor families who had nowhere else to go. And that’s how the Tenement Museum came to be. The Irish Outsiders tour narrates the life of a family in 1869.

 

St. Patrick’s Cathedral

Opened in 1879, St. Patrick’s Cathedral is a symbol of religious freedom and tolerance. Its astounding gothic architecture in the heart of Fifth Avenue has become a favorite spot for visitors from all over the world. Guided tours are available or download the app to take a self-guided tour.  

 

Irish Arts Center

To understand Irish heritage in the United States and its current influence, head to the Irish Arts Center for a taste of performances, visual arts and educational programs. Although its primary focus is Irish culture, the center has been promoting cross-cultural partnerships since 1979. Check out their calendar of events to see what’s on

 

St. Patrick’s Day Parade

This is the biggest St. Patrick’s Day Parade in the world. Maybe you should see it at least once. On March 17, thousands of marchers will put on traditional costumes to, well, march along Fifth Avenue fiddling, playing bagpipes and exhibit good ol’ Irish pride. The parade starts at 44th Street at 11am and ends at 79th Street at 5:00 p.m.
